I.  INTRODUCTION 
 
1.  The long-term strategic framework of the Asian Development Bank (ADB), Strategy 2030, 
prioritizes strengthening governance as one of the seven operational priorities committing ADB 
to promoting private sector development, good governance, gender equity, knowledge solutions, 
and partnerships.1 The Midterm Review of Strategy 2020 noted that weak governance and the 
0F
lack of transparency impede the effective delivery of basic services. Governance deficiencies can 
be addressed by a multipronged approach which includes the participation of the private sector 
in the development process and in delivering services.2 To assist with this endeavor, ADB’s Private 
1F
Sector Operations Department (PSOD) is proposing to conduct corporate governance assessments 
to strengthen the corporate governance structures and capacity in selected ADB early and midstage 
direct equity investments and corporate finance transactions where governance challenges have 
been identified.3 This activity is in accordance with ADB’s Operational Plan for Private Sector 
Operations, 2019–2024. 
 
2.  ADB is one of over 30 development finance institutions that, in 2011, committed to the 
Corporate Governance Development Framework.4 This commitment included integrating corporate 
governance  in  investment  operations,  ensuring  internal  responsibility,  providing  or  procuring 
corporate  governance  training,  collaborating  with  other  signatories,  and  reporting  on 
implementation of the framework.  
 
 
3. Corporate governance refers to the structures and processes for direction and control of 
companies and relationships among the management, board of directors or supervisory board, 
controlling  shareholders,  minority  shareholders,  and  other  stakeholders.  Good  corporate 
governance  makes  companies  stronger,  more  efficient,  and  accountable;  supports  the 
implementation  of  good  environmental  and  social  practices;  and  contributes  to  sustainable 
economic development by enhancing the performance of companies and increasing their access 
to outside capital.5 In emerging markets, good corporate governance can make companies more 
resilient to financial crisis, lower the cost of capital and transaction costs, provide employment, 
boost economic growth, and encourage new investment.6 
4F
 
4.  Early and midstage companies face a unique set of risks which they must surmount in 
order to succeed. Challenges may include inexperienced management, undercapitalization, rapid 
change, large consequences and small margins of error for decision-making, low levels of 
diversity (particularly among decision-makers), and overconfidence. This can prevent early and 
midstage companies from achieving optimal growth. Boards of these companies are often not 
well-equipped to assist on governance matters and may lack the independence to provide 
detached oversight and guidance.7  
5F
 
5.  Under this technical assistance (TA), PSOD will select early and midstage direct equity 
investments  and  corporate  finance  transactions  where  governance  challenges  have  been

identified and undertake corporate governance assessments.8 Private equity funds (and their 
portfolio investees) will not be eligible to participate in this project. Based on the governance 
assessments, and with the agreement of the participating companies, ADB will develop action 
plans  to  strengthen  corporate  governance  among  willing  participants.  For  companies  and 
enterprises willing to pursue the identified improvements, ADB will provide the necessary human 
resources to assist them through this TA project.  
 
II.  ISSUES 
 
6.  Companies  which  have  diverse  senior  management  expertise  often  outperform 
companies which do not. Good governance is correlated with strong organizational performance, 
and research shows that, for example, a gender-balanced workforce positively supports corporate 
performance in relation to company profitability, risk reduction, or share price. Companies with 
diverse boards receive higher scores on environmental, social, and governance performance; 
manage  risk  better;  and  have  a  more  comprehensive  understanding  of  key  company 
stakeholders.9 Moody’s recently reported that companies with greater gender diversity tend to 
have higher credit ratings, noting that this is a correlation rather than a cause.10 Women are under-
represented on corporate boards globally, and this is no different in Asia and the Pacific, where 
only one in five people in leadership positions are women. Even in developed economies, few 
women hold senior positions.11 ADB will seek to strengthen corporate diversity through this TA. 
Areas for improvement could include ensuring diverse, inclusive management; strengthening 
company policies to promote inclusivity; considering comparative compensation and benefits; or 
considering  revisions  to  human  resource  management  practices.  PSOD  management  will 
approve potential participants in accordance with its strategy.12 
 
7.  On occasion, ADB nominates nonexecutive directors to the boards of directors of its equity 
investee companies. These nominee directors are intended to add value to the board of directors 
and the client in areas where skills or experience gaps have been identified. Nominee directors 
provide  supplemental  skills  or  perspectives that  facilitate  the  growth and  prosperity  of the 
company, assist the board to discharge its functions more effectively, and establish or improve 
good governance practices. As part of this TA, ADB will arrange for annual training and capacity 
building for its nominee directors in areas such as directors’ fiduciary duties. ADB will also take 
the opportunity provided by these fora to promote its interest in maximizing potential gender and 
diversity initiatives in its investments and to encourage nominee directors to identify areas where 
these can be improved in the companies they serve.

III.  THE TECHNICAL ASSISTANCE 
 
A.  Impacts and Outcome 
 
8.  The TA is aligned with the following impact: strengthened corporate governance in private 
sector companies in Asia and the Pacific.13 There will also be individual project alignment with the 
Sustainable Development Goals according to their relevant sectors. The TA will have the following 
outcome: improved, more diverse corporate governance in private sector investments.14  
 
B.  Outputs, Methods, and Activities 
 
 
9. ADB  will  adopt the  corporate  governance  methodology  of the International  Finance 
Corporation (IFC),  which  served  as  the  basis for the  Corporate Governance  Development 
Framework adopted by ADB in September 2011 and other development finance institutions 
(footnote 4). The methodology was revised in 2018 to integrate environmental and social issues 
and reviews companies’ (i) commitment  to  environmental, social, and  corporate governance; 
(ii) structure and  functioning of the board of directors; (iii) control environment and processes; 
(iv) disclosure and transparency; (v) treatment of minority shareholders; and (vi) governance of 
stakeholder engagement.15 The framework will be modified to incorporate gender and diversity 
as an additional consideration.   
 
 
10. The methodology considers the maturity and complexity of companies and classifies them 
into four levels. At the first level are new or young companies with basic corporate governance 
frameworks,  or  those  without  an  environmental,  social,  and  governance  agenda.  Level  2 
companies have intermediate corporate governance practices in place incorporating basic steps 
to strengthen the environmental, social, and governance agenda. Level 3 companies demonstrate 
good international practices, including incorporating intermediate and other corporate governance 
practices that reflect the organization’s commitment to improvement. Level 4 companies are 
leaders in corporate governance, reflecting applied best practices. ADB will target companies 
assessed to be operating at levels 1–2 for action plans and further development. Level 3 
companies may also be considered for strategic improvements in areas identified to be weak. 
 
 
11. PSOD will engage corporate governance specialists with relevant industry and market 
experience to conduct inclusive corporate governance assessments and assist with implementing 
inclusive corporate governance action plans and capacity building. Tools are freely available to 
assist companies in undertaking the reviews themselves, or, as is proposed in this TA, with the 
assistance of experienced consultants who can serve as a resource in helping companies with 
both the assessment as well as the implementation and capacity building of good corporate 
governance action plans. Separately, annual nominee director trainings will be organized by ADB. 
This will strengthen the capacity of its nominees within companies in which ADB has invested or 
provided debt financing to ensure that their knowledge of areas such as directors’ fiduciary duties 
remains current and reflective of international best practices. It will also ensure these nominees 
maintain  their  awareness  of  issues  relevant  to  ADB’s  development  agenda,  including 
environmental, social, gender, and diversity objectives.   
 
 
13  ADB. 2001. Private Sector Operations Strategic Directions and Review. Manila. 
14  The design and monitoring framework is in Appendix 1. 
15   International Finance Corporation. IFC Corporate Governance Methodology.

4 
   
12. Output  1: Corporate  governance  assessments  conducted  and  action  plans 
developed for up to 10 companies. ADB will engage consultants who have experience in 
corporate  governance  assessment  as  well  as  in  developing  and  implementing  corporate 
governance action plans related to the business sector of the projects.16 
 
13.  Output 2: Corporate governance action plans are developed for six companies, five 
of which agree to pursue them. It is estimated that most of the participating companies will 
express interest in considering an action plan to strengthen corporate governance.17 Having 
reviewed the developed action plans, it is anticipated that five of the companies will request 
assistance to implement the plans and undertake capacity building initiatives. Thirty consultant 
days plus travel costs have been budgeted to assist the companies in pursuing the action plans. 
 
14.  Output 3: At least three companies improve gender and diversity frameworks. As 
part of the corporate governance assessment, opportunities to strengthen gender and diversity in 
participants’ management and operations will be identified for all participants. 
 
15.  Output 4: At least four annual nominee director training and capacity building 
events are held. Under this TA, PSOD and ADB’s Office of the General Counsel will conduct 
annual training and capacity building events at ADB headquarters for nominee directors. Flights, 
accommodation, and daily allowance for 18 nominee directors have been budgeted.  
 
16.  Output 5: Evaluation and lessons learned.  At the end of the TA, an evaluation specialist 
with experience working with corporate governance in private sector companies will be engaged 
to measure the impacts of the TA and to document lessons learned.   
 
17.   Additional activities and funding may be added to this TA to extend its scope to more than 
five companies. 
 
C.  Cost and Financing 
 
18.   The TA is estimated to cost $1.0 million, which will be financed on a grant basis by ADB’s 
Technical Assistance Special Fund ($750,000 TASF-6 and $250,000 TASF-other sources). The 
key expenditure items are listed in Appendix 2.   
 
D.  Implementation Arrangements 
 
19.  ADB will administer the TA. It will be implemented by PSOD’s Private Sector Transaction 
Support Division, which will lead the TA and will select, administer, and evaluate consultants and 
coordinate with PSOD’s investment officers about the outputs of the TA and further actions. 
PSOD’s  Portfolio  Management  Division,  which  ultimately  oversees  administration  of  the 
investments after disbursement and whose director represents PSOD in ADB’s Governance 
Thematic Group, will help identify potential clients and will participate in discussions about the 
results of the governance assessments, action plans, and subsequent implementation and 
capacity building work to strengthen corporate governance. ADB’s Office of the General Counsel 
will serve in an advisory capacity. The implementation arrangements are summarized in the table. 
 
 
16 The number of consultant days required is an estimate. The actual time frame of engagement will be determined on 
a case-by-case basis as participating companies are identified. It is estimated that each assessment will take 10 
days on average. 
17 Should more companies express interest, PSOD will seek to accommodate their interest. Thirty consultant days plus 
travel costs have been budgeted to assist the companies in pursuing the action plans.

and/or staff instructions. Procurement of equipment is not required. The terms of reference for the

provision for fixed out-of-pocket expenditures. Resource persons will be engaged for trainings, 
seminars, and conferences through single source selection. 
 
IV.  THE PRESIDENT'S DECISION 
 
21.   The President, acting under the authority delegated by the Board, has approved the 
provision of technical assistance not exceeding the equivalent of $1,000,000 on a grant basis for 
Strengthening  Corporate  Governance  in  ADB’s  Nonsovereign  Investments  in  Developing 
Member Countries, and hereby reports this action to the Board.
